body: AN urban farm off the East River. Artisanal food and crafts sold out of recycled shipping containers at the Dekalb Market. Smorgasburg and the Brooklyn Flea on the Williamsburg waterfront. They all share a hipper-than-thou aesthetic. They also share a pedigree: they were all set up to breathe some life into vacant lots. In an unlikely convergence
title: Send In the Food Trucks

body: Opening JAPADOG Japanese mayonnaise, teriyaki sauce, nori, daikon and soy sauce turn more than a dozen franks, including all beef, turkey and bratwurst, into Japanese hot dogs at this import from Vancouver: 30 St. Marks Place (Second Avenue), (646) 476-2324. JOE The most complete and technically advanced pour-over drip coffee bar will be part of
title: Off the Menu

body: The donor whose $350 million gift will be critical in building Cornell University's new high-tech graduate school on Roosevelt Island is Atlantic Philanthropies, whose founder, Charles F. Feeney, is a Cornell alumnus who made billions of dollars through the Duty Free Shoppers Group. Mr. Feeney, 80, has spent much of the last three decades giving
title: Cornell Alumnus Behind $350 Million Gift to Build Science School in the City

body: Stanford University abruptly dropped out of the intense international competition to build an innovative science graduate school in New York City, releasing its decision on Friday afternoon. A short time later, its main rival in the contest, Cornell, announced a $350 million gift -- the largest in its history -- to underwrite its bid. The twin
title: Stanford Ends Effort to Build New York Arm

body: TWO out-of-the-ordinary events happened on Saturday, Oct. 29, at Chelsea Market. One was the snowstorm outside. The other: a raucous cycling party inside. All shoppers had to do was follow the thumping girl-power music of Pink's ''Raise Your Glass'' or the gleeful ''Whew!'' yelled out every minute or so, and they would have arrived at the hot spot,
title: URBAN ATHLETE; A Workout Where You'd Least Expect It

body: Pop Ben Ratliff This week, two celebrations for musical explorers. On Tuesday the pianist and bandleader EDDIE PALMIERI -- who strengthened, refined and extended the Latin music tradition in New York: mambo, charanga, salsa, Afro-Latin funk, Latin jazz -- will celebrate his 75th birthday two days early by playing with his salsa orchestra at the
title: The Week Ahead | Dec. 11 - Dec. 17

body: Theater Jason Zinoman The holidays are typically a weak time for new plays but a very good one for star vehicles. I have made it a semiregular New Year's tradition to see SANDRA BERNHARD, who once again brings her acidic jokes, devilish gossip and stylish songs to Joe's Pub the last week of December. But you don't need to wait that long to see a
title: THE WEEK AHEAD; Dec. 11 -- 17

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: How are people reacting to the end of the N.B.A. lockout? Tepidly, I would say, judging from a quick swath of television interviews over the weekend. Even men in the playground, shooting hoops, professed ambiguity over the return of the rich guys. Then again, maybe it was the warm weather in the Northeast. People were outdoors, feeling good, not
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Welcoming Back N.B.A. With Open Yawns

body: Soon after buying 510 Fifth Avenue, a 1954 Gordon Bunshaft design praised as a paradigm of the International Style, Vornado Realty Trust began an interior renovation that it hoped would attract new street-level retail tenants. The work was to include new doorways on Fifth Avenue and to move escalators, among other things. The city had landmarked
title: The Tricky Task of Renovating a Building Without Altering Its Landmark Insides

body: DEAR DIARY: Watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade last year, I noticed that the turkey float had been retired. Years ago, I volunteered to be in the parade and had visions of being assigned to a position on top of a float or being asked to hold a balloon, which would give me an opportunity to see and wave to the crowd. I soon learned that I
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY; Flapping a Floating Turkey's Wing

body: Film Neil Genzlinger JOHN LANDIS has a new book out called ''Monsters in the Movies: 100 Years of Cinematic Nightmares,'' but an eight-film retrospective of his work at BAMcinématek opens on Monday at 4:30 p.m. -- cut out of work early! -- with laughs: ''National Lampoon's Animal House,'' the 1978 frat-house comedy that really put him on the map.
title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 20 - Nov. 26

body: Theater Ben Brantley Few contemporary American playwrights venture as intrepidly into foreign hot zones as J. T. ROGERS does. title: THE WEEK AHEAD; Nov. 20 -- 26

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: 'Civil Rights in Brooklyn: Stories of Struggle and Protest' (Sunday) A discussion, with archivists and audience participation, on the impact in Brooklyn of the civil rights movement, in celebration of its 50th anniversary. 128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718)
title: Spare Times

body: New York State's Family Courts were ordered to be opened to the public with much fanfare in 1997, supposedly allowing anyone to witness the cases of domestic violence, foster care and child neglect that inch through by the hundreds of thousands every year. But now, 14 years later, the Family Courts remain essentially, almost defiantly, closed to
title: Family Courts Say Keep Out, Despite Order

body: WHEN I visit a rural area, which I do only with great reluctance, there is often someone there urging me to awake before dawn with flashlight and steaming thermos, as if for a whale watch, and visit the local flea market. Though I love old things, this sense of urgency has never really resonated. Surely all the choicest tchotchkes and gewgaws won't
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; A Tidy Flea, But What To Buy?

body: On Tuesday, the day after one of the bleakest episodes in the history of the National Basketball Association -- when the players rejected the league's contract offer, disbanded their union and moved the season a step closer to being abandoned -- the Nets held a rally to promote their ''Brooklyn Experience'' outside Borough Hall. This was for a team
title: An Uncertain Season, but the Nets Celebrate in Brooklyn

body: Art Holland Cotter THE CLOISTERS, the Upper Manhattan branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art devoted to the art and architecture of medieval Europe, opens one of its infrequent special exhibitions on Tuesday, ''The Game of Kings: Medieval Ivory Chessmen From the Isle of Lewis.'' Unsurprisingly, the material on display -- chess pieces carved from
title: THE WEEK AHEAD; Nov. 13 -- 19

body: Pop/Jazz Ben Ratliff It is often said of Duke Ellington that his orchestra was his true instrument. A handful of jazz-inclined musician-philosophers have taken that idea one step further: they create their bodies of work by conducting groups of improvisers. Three of them, with imaginations that go far beyond the jazz tradition, are performing
title: The Week Ahead | Nov. 13-Nov. 19

body: Midway through a third term marked by budget-cutting and a series of political and managerial setbacks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of his inner circle are increasingly focused on the competition they created to build a high-tech graduate school in New York City, which many of them believe could become a major part of his legacy. So
title: NEWS ANALYSIS; In Mayor's Contest for a New Engineering School, Only One Judge Counts

body: Nine blocks from the steel shadow of Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, Gib Veconi circles Prospect Heights nightly in his 13-year-old Volvo wagon looking for a parking spot, like a buzzard scouring for a meal. Parking can be a blood sport in New York City, nowhere more so than along the crowded streets around the half-built Barclays Center in Downtown
title: Plan to Issue New Permits For Parking Is Debated

body: History is filled with cautionary tales of people who tarried too long on the stage. This is especially true of older women; we like to tell them when it's time to go. But Simone Forti was never one for traditional narratives. Born in 1935, she is among a generation of choreographers who, beginning in the 1950s, systematically upended accepted
title: DANCE REVIEW; Explorations, With Nature As Her Guide

body: New York City officials have been dreaming for months about a new graduate school bearing a prestigious brand name like Cornell or Stanford. But what about Amity University? Amity, an Indian university with campuses in Dubai and London, submitted one of seven bids for the city's support in building a school of engineering and applied sciences by
title: By Deadline, 7 Bids in Science School Contest

body: IN a city like New York with an aging housing stock -- much of it suffering from deferred maintenance -- brand-new condominiums have an obvious appeal. Luxury amenities like pools, screening rooms, children's play areas and high-end finishes can look pretty good when compared with a musty prewar building or a featureless postwar high-rise. And,
title: GETTING STARTED; Homework for Condo Buyers

body: Stanford University's proposed graduate school of science on Roosevelt Island carries a $2.5 billion price tag, the university said Wednesday, more than double its estimate just weeks ago. Stanford is a leading contender in the Bloomberg administration's competition to create a new school of applied sciences that officials hope will prompt the
title: Stanford's Estimated Cost For Science School Doubles

body: When one of the biggest real estate developments in Brooklyn was stalled two years ago, its owner turned to the city government for help, seeking $20 million in financing. Nearly 50 projects were applying for a small number of aid packages at the time, but this one, City Point, had a prominent supporter. ''The future of Downtown Brooklyn depends on
title: From Brooklyn Office, Mixing Clout and Charity

body: If Cornell University were to win the city's competition to build a new science graduate school, it would install on Roosevelt Island almost four acres of solar panels, 500 geothermal wells, and buildings with the rare distinction of generating as much power as they use. Stanford University's proposal for the island calls for minimizing energy use,
title: Environmental Features In Science Campus Plans

body: UPON finishing 10 years of active duty in the Army, Jeff Csoka lived and worked in New Jersey. Two years ago, after a divorce, he decided it was time to try city life. His intent was to rent in Manhattan for a year or so, get an idea of where and how he wanted to live, and then hunt for a bigger place. So, with the help of Shantal Cooper, a vice
title: THE HUNT; For a Bachelor Father, a Pad With a Pool

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Merchant's House Museum: Candlelight Ghost Tours (Friday and Saturday) Tours every half-hour from 6 to 9:30 p.m. of what some consider the most haunted house in Manhattan. 29 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 777-1089, merchantshouse.com; $25; $40 (includes servant's quarters); $13 for members. title: Spare Times

body: Because Yvelisse DeLeon of Coney Island was due at an interview for a bartending job on the evening of Jan. 25, 2007, she spent part of the afternoon getting herself ready. That process included a trip to Downtown Brooklyn. ''I went down here to get color for my hair,'' Ms. DeLeon, 35, testified this month in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. ''Jay
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Story Of Drugs And the Police

body: With less than two weeks left to apply in the competition for $400 million in land and subsidies to build a science and engineering graduate school in New York City, some of the world's great universities continue to change plans and jockey for position, and there is a growing view among them that Cornell and Stanford have emerged as the favorites.
title: 2 Top Suitors Are Emerging For New School Of Engineering

body: Had you been at Roulette, the theater in downtown Brooklyn, on Friday night, you would have learned -- or been reminded of -- a few things. Performing artists are unparalleled and exciting problem solvers, for example. The creative process, on the other hand, is often quite boring. And: the saints are the sinners who keep trying. This last nugget
title: DANCE REVIEW; A Performance From Soup to Nuttiness

body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

body: Never mind that attendance at the Guggenheim Museum in New York is nearly the highest it's ever been. When ''Picasso Black and White'' opens a year from now, expect a few more. Just as the public never seems to tire of Picasso shows, there also never seems to be an end to new takes and twists on his work. At the Guggenheim, Carmen Giménez, the
title: INSIDE ART; Picasso Will Return With Just Two Colors

body: Opening THE SMITH MIDTOWN With 150 seats in the main dining room alone, this uptown branch of Glenn Harris's and Jeffrey Lefcourt's successful place on the edge of the East Village is more deserving of their description of it as an American brasserie. Mr. Harris's straightforward menu of pastas, burgers, steaks, dishes like trout Milanese, and a
title: Off the Menu

body: When an orchestra wants to play outside it usually ends up in a park, a pastoral setting for picnicking and music that is familiar and not too demanding: Bernstein's ''West Side Story'' Suite, say, or Mozart's ''Jupiter'' Symphony. The audience is generally as white as the wine. That was what made the first preview of the rejuvenated Brooklyn
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Rap in and of Brooklyn, With the Rumble of the Subway Trains

body: The scarlet letter may have little currency left in the realm of sexual indiscretion, but it continues to be put to vigorous use among parents -- the shaming impulse particularly thrives in the wealthier precincts of brownstone Brooklyn, where the exacting standards of urbane motherhood would seem to have been invented. In a place where judgment is
title: BIG CITY; The Outcast of Brownstone Brooklyn

body: WITHIN the refuge of the studio choreographers are always on the lookout for a good mistake. Take ''Serenade,'' George Balanchine's luminous 1934 ballet, in which one dancer fell during rehearsal (Balanchine incorporated it), and another arrived late. (He used that too.) Now -- without the refuge -- the choreographer Sally Silvers is orchestrating
title: Choreographing as Fast as They Can

body: Help the Farmers Basic shelf-stable groceries are in short supply in the farming communities upstate that were affected by storms and floods. Donations of goods are being accepted at several Greenmarkets: grownyc.org/relief/collections. A pig roast with local fare will be held at Bridle Hill Farm, 190 Hemmer Road, Jeffersonville, N.Y., Oct. 15 from
title: Calendar

body: IT'S not as if Alan Pierson were hunting for a new job. A lean, sharp and energetic 37-year-old conductor, Mr. Pierson has made an enviable name for himself over the last decade as the artistic director of Alarm Will Sound, a vital, omnivorous 20-member chamber ensemble formed in 2001 by graduate students at the Eastman School of Music in
title: In Brooklyn, A New Leader Who Knows No Boundaries

title: The Listings

body: The Flavors of Africa A Taste of Africa, with food and performances, will be held on Wednesday from 6 p.m. until midnight at Taj Lounge, 48 West 21st Street; $10 at the door, plus $18 for a buffet of West African dishes and fusion items like African sushi. Drinks are extra. Some of proceeds will benefit victims of the Somalian drought. Of Chiles

body: The vagabond Nets - denizens of Newark, late of East Rutherford, N.J., and Long Island - will settle in downtown Brooklyn next year with a new identity but a familiar name. ''We named the New Jersey Nets the Brooklyn Nets,'' Jay-Z, the music mogul and part-owner of the franchise, announced Monday morning in a ceremony that was brief and
title: Moving to Brooklyn, but Still the Nets

body: IN 2006, when the Brooklyn Book Festival was in its first year, a panel discussion focused on how Brooklyn had shaped the writing of Jonathan Lethem, Paula Fox and Emily Barton. Pete Hamill and Jennifer Egan, both of Brooklyn, talked about their literary inspirations. Dramatic readings from the work of legendary Brooklyn writers were staged in a
title: Brooklyn Becomes Book Country Again

body: MOSCOW -- It has been a long time since a Russian billionaire attacked the political system. In the past, it has not ended well. On Thursday, Mikhail D. Prokhorov described Russia's party system as an elaborate sham orchestrated by a ''puppet master'' within the Kremlin walls. By the time he finished, Mr. Prokhorov seemed to have gambled with the
title: Billionaire Condemns Party He Led as a Kremlin 'Puppet'

body: Brooklyn's latest historic district - a cluster of 21 skyscrapers and office buildings surrounding Borough Hall downtown - was created on Tuesday over the objections of some of its landowners and inhabitants. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the Borough Hall Skyscraper Historic District despite opposition from business groups
title: Historic District in Brooklyn Is Approved, Despite Outcry

body: Days after the attacks, researchers at the Columbia Center for Oral History began asking New Yorkers to describe their experience of the most harrowing day in the city's history. The following account, the fall of the trade center told moment by moment and person by person, is drawn from the more than 600 interviews collected in the September 11,
title: THE 9/11 DECADE; Witness to Apocalypse

body: A faculty strike that disrupted the first week of school at Long Island University could come to an end on Monday, both sides said Friday after a new round of negotiations produced the outlines of a deal. ''We're hopeful to have a proposal to put before the membership for ratification Monday,'' said Edward J. Donahue, the president of the Long
title: Deal May Be Near in L.I.U. Strike

body: DENNY SHEEHAN liked what he saw when he checked out the ground-floor one-bedroom in Cobble Hill on his lunch hour. The apartment, with a small extra room, was larger than others he had seen for a similar price, $2,050 a month. So, last summer, he and his girlfriend, Aimée Scala, moved in. From then on, they regretted it almost every day. The
title: THE HUNT; What? Can't Hear You! Let's Move

body: FOR its first retail endeavor, the Brooklyn design incubator 3rd Ward thought inside the box -- specifically, a salvaged shipping container. Shopbox, as they're calling it, opened Aug. 26 at the Dekalb Market in Downtown Brooklyn, where all of its neighbors are also housed in repurposed storage units. Painted a can't-miss green, with prominent
title: Unwrapped

body: JANELLE MONÁE was somewhere on the Adriatic coast, sipping coconut juice and watching ''Oprah,'' but she was thinking about a parking lot in Brooklyn. It was there, playing one of the first Afro-Punk Festivals in the shadow of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, that Ms. Monáe, the retro-modernist R&B and hip-hop chanteuse known for her wildly
title: Beats, Bikes, Skateboards And the Big Time

body: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may be criticized for its weekend service suspensions, broken escalators and packed L trains. But don't ever call it unfashionable. When it came time for the authority to choose a color to represent the Second Avenue subway line, officials did not give this fashion-focused city another line colored in
title: Train Line Far From Arrival Has a Color To Be Noticed

body: ACCESS to public transportation is vital in New York City. But for those considering a move to the city -- or even just to a new neighborhood -- proximity to a subway station is only the first step in determining how easy it will be to get around. You will also need to know how frequently and reliably a subway runs, and whether you'll be plagued by
title: GETTING STARTED; Can You Get There From Here?

body: It is unlikely that any visitors to the property assessor's office in the stone monolith known as the Brooklyn Municipal Building ever looked around at the clerks poring over tax records and exclaimed, ''It would be fun to spend my next paycheck here.'' But the Laboz brothers think it could be just that sort of place. On Monday, Mayor Michael R.
title: City Selling Space in Brooklyn Building

body: Art Carol Vogel Powerful portraits of politicians, musicians, actors and other well-known personalities including a model and a professional golfer are the subject of ''TIMOTHY GREENFIELD-SANDERS: THE LATINO LIST,'' an exhibition that opens Friday at the Brooklyn Museum. In addition to large-format color photographs, the show will include excerpts
title: THE WEEK AHEAD; Aug. 14 -- 20

body: Theater Charles Isherwood The New York theater troupe THE CIVILIANS is summering in the Berkshires. The company, which specializes in documentary theater pieces drawn from extensive interviews, is creating its new show on the Nikos Stage at the Williamstown Theater Festival. Although it is also based on real experience, ''YOU BETTER SIT DOWN: TALES
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | AUG. 14 - AUG. 20

body: Three to five minutes, Chris Mullin was told, and this made him happy, a little bit relieved. He would not have to speak all that long, notwithstanding how far his oratory skills have come since the days when he mostly spoke a sign language of his own, with a ball or a beer. ''Short and concise,'' he said of the acceptance speech he was planning
title: A Time For Thanks

body: In the safety of her therapist's office in late 2001, Dr. Margaret Dessau made a tape reliving what it was like to look out her living room window after she heard the boom of a hijacked plane eight blocks away. Running naked from her bath, she saw pigeons and paper flying through the air. ''It's kind of beautiful in a way,'' she recalls on the
title: 10 Years and a Diagnosis Later, 9/11 Demons Haunt Thousands

But here's the good news: The park offers young anglers two fishing clinics every Saturday for most of the summer. You do the math (even if it is school vacation). Macy's Fishing Clinics (the Macy's Foundation underwrites them, as it
title: Spare Times

body: A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough. The advocates identified at least 5 of the 17 hospitals in the borough --
title: Hospitals In Brooklyn Defended At Hearing

body: The Brooklyn Philharmonic has announced its first season under a new music director, Alan Pierson: a slate of grab-bag community concerts with a strong popular-music inflection. The organization will offer a series of concerts in three neighborhoods -- Brighton Beach, Bedford-Stuyvesant and downtown Brooklyn -- to be played in theaters, at a
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Philharmonic Announces Season

body: Dead of summer, but still the postman trudges forth to the mountaintop with questions for Mr. Critic, meditating on his zafu pillow. This week brought queries about a first-time trip to New York City, about where to feed a world-weary New Yorker and about where to hold a rehearsal dinner for American expatriates in from London and seeking British
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; New York at First Bite: Oh, the Places You'll Go

body: There is not enough evidence yet to say whether the dust and smoke cloud produced by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center caused cancer, federal officials concluded in a report released on Tuesday. The finding, based on an initial review required by a new federal law, disappointed rescue and recovery workers and people who lived near the
title: Not Enough Evidence to Link 9/11 and Cancer, a Federal Report Says

body: IN late 2008, Susan Holland met the Tony-winning Broadway producer Hal Luftig and his longtime partner, Stewart Adelson, a psychiatrist, at their Chelsea loft to discuss the wedding reception the two were planning for the coming spring. ''I was thinking afternoon cocktails,'' said Mr. Luftig, who had legally married Mr. Adelson in October. Mr.
title: WITH THIS RING . . .; Star Party Planner Is at the Ready

body: For Children 'Angelina Ballerina the Musical' (Sunday) That winsome white mouse who does all her scurrying in toeshoes has pirouetted back onto the stage. Vital Theater Company has revived its musical adaptation of the books by Katharine Holabird and Helen Craig and the PBS series ''Angelina Ballerina the Next Steps.'' The show, by Susan DiLallo
title: Spare Times

body: By Saturday, 22 shipping containers in an array of colors will be in place for the opening of Dekalb Market, a collection of food, clothing and other retailers in downtown Brooklyn that will be open year-round. Ten food vendors have signed one-year leases for the 160-square-foot containers, some open on the long side with a counter and others open
title: FOOD STUFF; A Brooklyn Market With Vendors in Colorful Containers

body: In a blow to St. Ann's Warehouse, a widely admired theater in Brooklyn, a judge has issued a ruling that essentially nullifies a set of decisions by the federal, state and city governments over the last several years that led to approval of a new home for the theater. The judge, Eric N. Vitaliano of Federal District Court, had issued a preliminary
title: Ruling Ends Theater's Bid For Brooklyn Waterfront

body: An article on Thursday about an alliance between the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Barclays Center, the arena being built in downtown Brooklyn, misstated the title for Joseph V. Melillo of the academy. He is its executive producer, not executive director.
title: Corrections

body: It's been a springboard for Brooklyn nostalgia, a debate about urban design and the politics of eminent domain and, depending on your perspective or basketball affiliation, a community uniter or divider. Now Atlantic Yards, the development that will bring the New Jersey Nets to downtown Brooklyn, will also be a cultural center. The Barclays Center,
title: In Alliance, Nets Arena To Offer Arts

body: Leaders of the Theater for a New Audience, one of New York's premier Shakespearean troupes, reached a milestone on Friday in their decades-long dream for a home as they held a groundbreaking ceremony for a $47.5 million theater. The project represents an unusually large financial commitment by the city to move an arts organization -- in this case,
title: Shakespeare Troupe Starts Building Brooklyn Theater

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum: 19th-century baseball (Saturday) A game of old-fashioned baseball, played according to 19th-century rules and in period costumes by the New York Mutuals and the Mineola Washingtons, is scheduled for 1 p.m. There will also be a demonstration of rounders, a precursor to baseball, and house
title: Spare Times

body: When Mildred Furiya moved to a 19th-century town house on State Street in Brooklyn from a cramped walkup in Greenwich Village in 1967, a boarding house known for prostitution stood across a barren street, groups of unemployed men hung out on the corner and the Brooklyn House of Detention was a defining presence a block away. Standing in the garden
title: THE APPRAISAL; Her $16,000 Town House, Now Available for Just $1.879 Million More

body: CHEF'S TABLE AT BROOKLYN FARE 200 Schermerhorn Street (Hoyt Street), downtown Brooklyn; (718) 243-0050; brooklynfare.com/chefs-table. César Ramirez worked for David Bouley at Bouley and at Danube, and his cooking at this restaurant in downtown Brooklyn has some of Mr. Bouley's precision and passion, his respect for pure ingredients. A tiny serving
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: After 10 months organizing an underground production of Lanford Wilson's 1965 drama, ''Balm in Gilead,'' Beau Willimon reached a dream-come-true moment on Thursday afternoon: His cast of 25 actors, drawn from across the country and given just days to work, was rehearsing for the first time in its 15,000-square-foot playing area in a South Brooklyn
title: A Theater Is Conjured, Then Leaves Only Memory

body: RIVER LOFTS, a condominium at Laight and West Streets in TriBeCa, has attracted buyers like Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin, who live in a spectacular all-white apartment. At the same time, the building's exterior has required such extensive repairs that, for much of the four years since it opened, it has looked more like a construction site than
title: All Filled Upstairs, But Empty Below

body: There was a rally on May 12, when seasoned protesters convened by the thousands near City Hall to stake their claim against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget. There were gatherings at subway stations organized by the city's public advocate, Bill de Blasio, at which hundreds of parents recorded messages and signed petitions against cuts to their
title: In Schools Budget Fight, It's Not Just the Usual Players

body: THE ASTOR ROOM 34-12 36th Street (35th Avenue), Astoria, Queens; (718) 255-1947; astorroom.com. This refurbished commissary of Kaufman Astoria Studios, a vast complex of sound stages near the Museum of the Moving Image, is an odd but rewarding new spot. The Astor Room's owner, Chris Vlacich, has made the ambitious decision to insert a Jazz
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: Some may think that in summer, the city gets quiet, the traffic starts to die down a bit, and the brisk pace of the business suits slows to a saunter in a sundress. Some would be wrong. That's when the city gets rowdy with music festivals, parades, celebrations of art and food, and most of it at small cost. With so much going on, it's easy to let
title: Hot City, A Guide

body: ''I don't want to miss my cue,'' the festively dressed man sitting next to me explained as he edged his chair closer to see the left side of the tableau before us: 120 people arrayed over tiered platforms at one end of the extraordinary Skylight One Hanson, a majestic Art Deco space in the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, a towering
title: PERFORMANCE REVIEW; In Brooklyn, a Boschscape Of Vows, Song and Flesh

body: 9:51 p.m. | Updated The United Federation of Teachers filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in an effort to halt two tools the city's Education Department uses to change the school system: closing schools for poor performance and giving charter schools space in buildings occupied by traditional public schools. The litigation, filed in State Supreme Court,
title: Teachers' Union Files Suit To Stop School Closings

body: It was about 20 minutes into the bidding on Sunday and only one apartment remained to be sold at 1 Hanson Place, the high-profile condo made from the old Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, once the tallest in Brooklyn. The five other penthouses for sale had already gone to buyers at deep discounts of their original asking prices, and the final
title: THE APPRAISAL; Sold! Six Penthouses Soaring Over Brooklyn

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: Be careful. Be very careful what you wish for. And whatever you do, never underestimate the power of negative thinking. title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; A Cosmic Comeuppance for the Dodgers

body: ''PARDON me,'' said César Ramirez. Thus begins a meal at one of the more extraordinary restaurants in New York City. Mr. Ramirez is the chef at the Chef's Table at Brooklyn Fare, on Schermerhorn Street in downtown Brooklyn. He stood like a ship's captain in front of the immense Molteni stove that is the centerpiece of his kitchen, the hearth
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; 20 Courses, Bite by Bite

body: Once they were the shipshape town houses of the Brooklyn Navy Yard's senior officers, but now the gray buildings sit like ruins encountered in a jungle, their facades, roofs and interiors overgrown with ivy, weeds, even saplings. The punched-out windows and doors, rusted railings and vandalized rooms of Admiral's Row have become a blight in an
title: BROOKLYN NAVY YARD JOURNAL; A Battle Over Preservation in a Strip Once Worthy of Admirals

title: Spare Times

title: Mourning Short Life Of Victim Of Beating

body: When Amber Brien, a 36-year-old researcher by day and bass guitar player by night, put her sun-filled sixth-floor condominium near Downtown Brooklyn up for sale last March, she thought it would not be long before she sold it and moved in full time with her boyfriend in Park Slope. Since then, her boyfriend has become her fiancé and her music jobs
title: APPRAISAL; How a Building Dispute Can Sink a Sale

body: The subway escalators that run under the brick high-rise at the corner of East 15th Street in Union Square have long been in a near-constant state of disrepair. title: SQUARE FEET; Developers in New York Try to Ease Subway Issues

body: It was a relatively routine call, the kind that the New York City police usually handle without too much trouble. A frightened woman in Brooklyn telephoned 911 early Sunday morning and reported that her ex-boyfriend was threatening her. ''He said he's going to kill me,'' the woman cried. ''He said he's across the street, and he's going to kill me
title: Hours Apart, Two Officers Die in the Line of Duty: In Brooklyn, Falling Over a Railing In a Scuffle

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. title: The Listings

body: You have to admire Lynn Parkerson, the director of the Brooklyn Ballet, for not exactly pandering to popular taste through most of the company's current program at the Performance Space at the Schermerhorn. That program, ''From Baroque to Hip-Hop -- Reconstructions, Revivals and New Choreography,'' seen on Sunday, is the company's first at this
title: DANCE REVIEW; Connecting the Dots, From the 18th Century to the Hip-Hop Now

body: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and ''we took up the entire basement,'' Mr. Alvarez said. Somehow they had accumulated an array of space-hogging clothes,
title: THE HUNT; A Move Dictated by Miscellany

title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Kittens With Jet Packs? Not Yet, But These Inventors Are on It

Empire had been the fourth-largest tenant at the World Trade Center, and the shell-shocked executives were already thinking about new offices. Mr. Stuckey
title: SQUARE FEET; Born of 9/11, an Effort to Rebuild Shattered Haiti

body: Pierre Lucien, 27, has to learn how to walk again, with no legs, and with new legs. A police officer on medical leave who has lived in New York since leaving Haiti in 1989, Mr. Lucien was running at a police training facility three years ago when he collapsed -- and he has not felt the ground since. He contracted rhabdomyolosis, a disorder in which
title: LENS; The Realm of the Senses

body: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. The moral of the story is a memo to the Knicks and their impetuous owner, James L. Dolan. Don't go to sleep on the tall Russian who owns the team across the river. He plays roulette. ''Ecstatic and excited'' was how Billy King, the Nets' general manager, described Mikhail D. Prokhorov after King called to say he had landed
title: ON BASKETBALL; Nets' Master of Roulette May Have Pulled a Fast One

body: George Bugliarello, who as president of Polytechnic Institute of New York spearheaded the creation of MetroTech, a 16-acre research park that spurred development in Downtown Brooklyn, died on Friday in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 83. The cause was complications from pneumonia, his wife, Virginia, said. Dr. Bugliarello lived in Port Washington, N.Y. In the
title: George Bugliarello, 83, Visionary Engineer

body: Bob Diamond has spent nearly his entire adult life curating the Atlantic Avenue train tunnel in Downtown Brooklyn, an abandoned 19th-century rail line that once ran beneath Atlantic Avenue between Court and Hicks Streets. Mr. Diamond, 51, located the tunnel as a teenager and got the city to let him go down a manhole while wearing tennis shorts and
title: CITY ROOM; A Tunnel's Guide Fights to Get Back Inside

body: International VIEWING OF PROTESTS LEADS To Arrests in Zimbabwe Dozens of students, trade unionists and political activists who gathered to watch Al Jazeera and BBC news reports on the uprisings that brought down autocrats in Tunisia and Egypt have been arrested on suspicion of plotting to oust President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. title: Inside The Times

author: Naima Coster, a writer, is earning her master's in English at Fordham University.
body: I HAVE always felt as if Brooklyn belonged to me. At the very least, Fort Greene was mine. While I was growing up in the late 1980s and the 1990s, Fort Greene was notorious for being a rough neighborhood, home to one of New York City's largest public housing projects. For most of my life, this provided me with incredible and undue street cred: I
title: NEW YORK STORY; Remembering When Brooklyn Was Mine

body: AT his house in New Rochelle, Reginald Johnson cooked and baked in his dream kitchen, where he used a 60-inch-wide Wolf range to make delicacies like butternut squash ravioli and rosemary-olive-oil cake. title: THE HUNT; Space for Spices, Gadgets and Guests

title: Chasing Crime, But Foiled By Traffic

title: Suit Over 109 Square Feet in Condo Shines Light on How Homes Are Measured

title: ON BASKETBALL; For the Nets, A Brooklyn Stars Can't See

author: Andrew Cotto is a writer who lives in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and teaches in Downtown Brooklyn.
body: As a student and a teacher of language, I appreciate curses and other vulgarities: they can add color and emphasis to our vernacular. The distinction between where it is and is not appropriate to curse - and I am not just talking
title: COMPLAINT BOX | OBSCENITIES; Any Profanity-Free Zones Left on the Planet?

body: SALLY DIMICELI'S CAREER began 49 years ago at the Helen Keller Services for the Blind on Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn, when, at age 18, she got a job as a cashier. She worked in that capacity until 1994, when she was promoted into the fund-raising and development position she has now. Ms. DiMiceli retired on Friday, along with her best
title: SHUT & OPEN; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: EVERY January, the mayor stands at a lectern and delivers the State of the City address, a snapshot of the metropolis from 30,000 feet, with a few local details -- a new fishing pier here, a new middle-income housing development there -- tossed in to help make his case that the government is hard at work to make your life better. That's one
title: The State of the Blocks: Not All Rosy

body: NEWARK As N.B.A. owners go, Mikhail D. Prokhorov doesn't exactly play hard to get, at least not in America. title: ON BASKETBALL; An Evening of Russian Candor

body: AT the height of the real estate boom in Manhattan, it seemed a new glass-walled apartment tower was unveiled every week and sold out before the next one even got its Web site up. Now, as the market plods along in a slow but steady recovery, brokers and developers are saying the city will soon face a shortage of new development projects. Skeptics
title: Why Your Next Place May Cost More

body: Time was, clouds gathered over the frigid city and released moisture that fell to the land not in liquid form, but in a semi-hardened state that the people called ''snow.'' The people waited for the snow to stop falling, and they worked to clear enough from the roads so as to access without interruption institutions of commerce, entertainment and
title: Flakes May Not Pile Up, But the Anxiety Will

body: THE view north across the East River from a high floor at Oro, a new 40-story condominium tower at 306 Gold Street in Downtown Brooklyn, is eye-popping, a panorama of clouds, bridges, water and skyscrapers in Manhattan. title: Suddenly, A Brooklyn Skyline

body: All together, the seven strips of greenery hardly seem substantial enough to amount to a park. Someone unfamiliar with Greenwich Village might pass them by as ornamental to their adjoining buildings, like extra-wide hedges. But to many residents in and around the two sprawling apartment complexes owned by New York University, these oblong borders
title: GREENWICH VILLAGE JOURNAL; 7 Strips of Green, Or a Park Worth Fighting For?
